instruction: What metric was chosen to improve the classification of tree species in an urban area, and how far can this metric go in terms of accuracy?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the classification performance to improve the classification of tree species in an urban area is the F-score. The F-score is a measure that combines precision and recall, providing a balanced assessment of the classification accuracy. It takes into account both the number of correctly classified instances (precision) and the number of instances correctly identified as belonging to a specific class (recall). 

In terms of accuracy, the F-score can range from 0 to 100%. A higher F-score indicates better classification performance, with 100% representing perfect classification accuracy. In the related study, the F-score values for the Visible Near-Infrared range from greater than 60% for 13 out of 15 species on the reference site. The Short-Wavelength Infrared achieves an F-score greater than 60% for seven common species with the Visible Near-Infrared. The overall accuracy achieved with the best fusion strategy is 77% (kappa = 74%), which is slightly higher than the 75% (kappa = 72%) achieved by the Visible Near-Infrared alone. 

Therefore, while the F-score provides a useful metric for evaluating classification performance, it is important to note that the accuracy achieved in this study is not perfect and there is still room for improvement.
